titleStmt.title: William Morris to Thomas Pennant, 28 July 1757

div.p: Doctor Ellis and my self arrived safe at this our Castrum abot. 3 Days ago, where we found all well,William Morris had been absent from home for a fortnight on a fossil-hunting expedition, travelling through four Welsh counties and visiting Thomas Pennant at Downing. See his letter of 24 July 1757 to his brother Lewis, where he writes that he reached home the previous evening. ML, II, p. 494. the Day after our return a ship Arrived here from Barbadoes to discharge Sugar it was lucky that she did not come in my Absence.As deputy comptroller of the customs at Holyhead, William Morris would have needed to maintain a presence when ships returning from distant and lucrative voyages such as the one named here docked. See his reference to weighing a load of more than two hundred tons from a sugar ship which came into the port in August 1754, and his wistful comment on the difficulties of gaining any material benefit from this work because of a rivalry with the other Anglesey port of Beaumares. William to Richard, 23 August 1754, in ML, I, p. 305.

Your conjecture abot. Maen Chwyfan being a Cross set up by Christians on some religious occasion is Confirm'd by Two Pillars much resembling it in Disert Church yard.Pennant closes his discussion of Maen Achwyfan in A tour in Wales (2nd edn., 1784), p. 13, noting that it is like 'other pillars of antient date in several parts of Great Britain' 'evidently a Christian monument'. For images of two Celtic crosses now housed in the interior of the Parish Church of St Bridget, Dyserth, but formerly placed in the churchyard, see here [accessed 15 July 2020]. One of them stands endwise in a reclining posture & call'd by the Natives y Groes (ie) the Cross; is abot. 5 feet out of the Ground wrought all over wth. embellishments but no Figures of Animals or Letters that i could perceive. The Other lying Edgewise in the Church yard wall & made use of for a Stile embelishe like the Other. the Cross on the Top in each Juts out a little at the Ends, & each imbossd at the Centre like your Maen.

I observ'd that the House where mr. Ellis of Disert lives is built of a Limestone in which are stratas of Flinty matter resembling that mention'd by WoodwardWilliam Morris refers to the work of John Woodward, An attempt towards a natural history of the fossils of England (1729), which contains several references to Arkendale. to be at Arkendale in Yorkshire, Time wd. admit of my Going to Examine the Quarry where it was dug.

I proposed going to Llan Dydno in my return in search of some of the many Curiosities mention'd by Mr. Lhwyd, but the time failed the Jubilee at Conway likewise prevented my having the pleasure of seeing Mr. Holand to deliver your Message &c

Having met with some recent AlcyoniumsThe application of the word 'alcyonium' to denote a genus of coral dates from work by Linnaeus in 1758 and thus post-dates this letter. The meaning here therefore relates to sessile marine invertebrates, in particular soft corals and sponges. See OED. betwixt Penman Rhôs and Rhôs Fynach. I took hold of the first Opportunity of Coneying them you, in hopes you would receive them before they were emaciated. they were the Alc. ramoso-digitatum molle &c of Ray's Syn. Pa. 31.As indicated here, Ray refers to the 'Alcyonium ramoso-digitatum molle' on p. 31 of his Synopsis methodica stirpium Britannicarum (1690; 3rd edn., London: Gulielmi & Joannis Innys Regiae Societatis Typographorum, 1724). – Had yo. seen one of them when first ta'en out of the Sea, you certainly wd. have concluded them to be the Originals of Mr. Lhwyd's Cartilago Mamillaris sive uber vaccinum &c of which he hath given an Icon –William Morris refers to Edward Lhuyd's Lithophylacii Britannici ichnographia (1699). The 'Cartilago mamillaris, sive uber vaccinum referens' is listed as no. 1522 on p. 78, with an icon in Table 18.

The Plant calld by your Gardiner Bladder Flatmina,The reading of 'Flatmina' is clear, but cf. 'Ketmia' below and the examples of 'bladder ketmia' cited in OED s.v. flower, n., goodnight, n., int., and adj., and modesty. The quotations including this form equate the 'Bladder Ketmia' with the 'Hibiscus Trionum', 'Trionum annuum', and the English name 'flower of an hour'. wch. I took at first to be the Corchorus. I find is the Alcea Peregrina of Gerard, or Venice Mallow of wch. he gave a bad Icon.See John Gerard, The herball or Generall historie of plantes (1633 edn.), p. 936, for a description and an icon of the Alcea Peregrina or Venice Mallow. And is the Alcea Peregrina Sive vesicaria of Parkinson's Parad. who gives a good Icon and a description that exactly Answers in all respects.For the 'Alcea peregrina sive vesicaria' in John Parkinson's Paradisi in sole paradisus terrestris, or, A Garden of All Sorts of Pleasant Flowers ... with a Kitchen Garden ... and an Orchard , see pp. 368, 370, and for an icon entitled 'Alcea Veneta. The Venice Mallow', ibid. p. 367, no. 2. Parkinson notes several Latin names, concluding that 'The most usuall english name is Venice Mallow'. Gerard is mistaken in the time the Flower shuts, which is as soon as it feels the heat of the Sun, & not at noon.See Gerard, The herball or Generall historie of plantes (London, 1633), p. 937: 'it openeth it selfe about eight of the clocke, and shutteth vp againe at noone, about twelue a clock when it hath receiued the beams of the Sun, for two or three houres, whereon it should seeme to reioice to look, and for whose departure, being then vpon the point of declension, it seemes to grieue, and so shuts vp the floures that were open, and neuer opens them againe'. You'll find it in Miller under the name of Ketmia (Vessicaria). 19This is a reference to Joseph Miller, The gardener's dictionary (1731). The name 'Ketmia vesicaria vulgaris' appears as no. 19 under the entries for 'Hibiscus', with the names 'Common Bladder Ketmia, called Venice Mallow, or Flower of an hour' also given. See ibid. (8th edn., London, 1768), unpaginated. should be glad of some of the Seed for this important discovery.

I have sorted the Few Fossils &c brot. with me, & now begin to Long for the Arrival of the Grand Cargo.William Morris had evidently sent material gathered on his journey to Flintshire back to his home in Holyhead by sea. Here are no Vessels as yet bound to your Parts. — I hope Morva Rhuddlan is daily improving, the Few men that were employd there the 22d Inst. were a Burlesque upon Roadmaking, and if an Estimate was to be made from their performance it must be a Dear Jobb indeed ––– May the Counties of Denbigh, Carnarvon & Anglesey follow your Laudable Example that North-wales may be no more A terror to Travelers. –The responsibility for road maintenance at this time lay in the hands of local parishes, operating through the High Constable and the Quarter Sessions. See Bryn Ellis, 'Flintshire Quarter Sessions Rolls 1752–1830', Flintshire Historical Society Journal, 36 (2003), 96–113. The work in question here, however, may be linked to a parliamentary act. 'An Act for amending, widening, and keeping in Repair, the Roads from the Town of Wrexham ... to Pentre Bridge in the County of Flint, and from the Town of Mold to Northop, Holywell, and Rhuddlan, in the same County, and from thence to The Ferryhouse opposite the Town of Conway in the County of Carnarvon, and from Ruthin to the said Town of Mold' was among a series of Bills presented to be passed before the House of Lords on 28 June 1757. See Journals of the House of Lords (1688–1834), vol. 6, p. 188, here [accessed 19 July 2020]. Mr. Ellis Joins with me in humble respects to your Worthy Father & SistersPennant's twin sisters, Sarah and Catherine. and Compliments to your good Self we shall always retain the warmest gratitude for all Civilities receiv'd at Downing –

closer.salute:
I am
Dr. Sir
your most obliged humble Servt.
